questions.ocrQuestion:
Let \( \vec{a}=2 \hat{i}+\hat{j}-2 \hat{k} \) and \( \vec{b}=\hat{i}+\hat{j} \). If \( \vec{c} \) is a vector such that \( \vec{a} \cdot \vec{c}=|\vec{c}|,|\vec{c}-\vec{a}|=2 \sqrt{2} \) and the angle between \( \vec{a} \times \vec{b} \) and \( \vec{c} \) is \( 30^{\circ} \), then \( |(\vec{a} \times \vec{b}) \times \vec{c}| \) is
(a) \( 2 / 3 \)
(b) \( 3 / 2 \)
(c) 2
(d) 3

questions.ocrQuestion:
For any vector \( \vec{A} \), which of the following statements is true?
(a) \( \overrightarrow{\mathrm{A}}=(\vec{A} \times \hat{i}) \hat{i}+(\vec{A} \times \hat{j}) \hat{j}+(\vec{A} \times \hat{k}) \hat{k} \)
(b) \( \overrightarrow{\mathrm{A}}=(\vec{A} \times \hat{i}) \cdot \hat{i}+(\vec{A} \times \hat{j}) \cdot \hat{j}+(\vec{A} \times \hat{k}) \cdot \hat{k} \)
(c) \( \overrightarrow{\mathrm{A}}=(\vec{A} \cdot \hat{i}) \hat{i}+(\vec{A} \cdot \hat{j}) \hat{j}+(\vec{A} \cdot \hat{k}) \hat{k} \)
(d) \( \overrightarrow{\mathrm{A}}=(\vec{A} \cdot \hat{i}) \times \hat{i}+(\vec{A} \cdot \hat{j}) \times \hat{j}+(\vec{A} \cdot \hat{k}) \times \hat{k} \)

The value of the constant ' \( \mathrm{m} \) ' for which \( \vec{A}=m \hat{i}+\hat{j}+\sqrt{5} \hat{k} \) subtends an angle \( 60^{\circ} \) with \( \vec{B}=4 \hat{i}-5 \hat{j}+\sqrt{5} \hat{k} \) is equal to
(a) \( \sqrt{46 / 3} \)
(b) \( \sqrt{29 / 4} \)
(c) \( \sqrt{41 / 3} \)
(d) \( \sqrt{17 / 3} \)

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The range of \( \mathrm{x} \) for which the angle between the vectors \( \vec{A}=2 x^{2} \hat{i}+4 x \hat{j}+\hat{k} \) and \( \vec{B}=7 \hat{i}-2 \hat{j}+x \hat{k} \) is obtuse, is equal to
(a) \( x < 0 \)
(b) \( x>1 / 2 \)
(c) \( 0 < x < 1 / 2 \)
(d) None of these
questions.onlyq_text: The range of \( \mathrm{x} \) for which the angle between the vectors \( \vec{A}=2 x^{2} \hat{i}+4 x \hat{j}+\hat{k} \) and \( \vec{B}=7 \hat{i}-2 \hat{j}+x \hat{k} \) is obtuse, is equal to
questions.sol_html: Angle \( \theta \) between vector \( \vec{a} \) and \( \vec{b} \)\[\cos \theta=\frac{\vec{a} \cdot \vec{b}}{|\vec{a}||\vec{b}|}\]for obtuse angle,\[\begin{array}{l}\cos \theta<0 \\\vec{a} \cdot \vec{b} \\|\vec{a}||\vec{b}| \\\vec{a} \cdot \vec{b}<0 \\14 x^{2}-8 x+x<0 \\(7 x)(2 x-1)<0 \\0<x<\frac{1}{2}\end{array}\]Hence anlge between given vectors are obtuse if \( x \in\left(0, \frac{1}{2}\right) \)
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
A particle moves along the curve \(x=2 t^{2}, y=t^{2}-4 t, z=3 t-5\). The components of its acceleration at \(t=1\) in the direction \(\hat{i}-3 \hat{j}+2 \hat{k}\), is equal to
(a) \(2 / \sqrt{14}\)
(b) \(-2 / \sqrt{14}\)
(c) \(16 / \sqrt{14}\)
(d) \(-16 / \sqrt{14}\)
questions.onlyq_text: A particle moves along the curve \(x=2 t^{2}, y=t^{2}-4 t, z=3 t-5\). The components of its acceleration at \(t=1\) in the direction \(\hat{i}-3 \hat{j}+2 \hat{k}\), is equal to

sol_html.solution:
given  \[ x=2 t^{2} \\ y=t^{2}-4 t \\ \quad z=3 t-5 \\ \quad a_{x}=\frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}=4, a_{y}=\frac{d^{2} y}{d t^{2}}=2, a_{2}=\frac{d^{2} z}{d t^{2}}=0 \\ \therefore \quad \vec{a}=4 \hat{i}+2 \hat{j}  \]

Component of \(\vec{a}\) in the direction of \(\hat{i}-3 \hat{j}+2 \hat{k}\) is

\[ \frac{(4 \hat{\imath}+2 \hat{\jmath}) \cdot(\hat{\imath}-3 \hat{\jmath}+2 \hat{k})}{\sqrt{14}}=\frac{-2}{\sqrt{14}} \]

questions.sub_topic_name: Dot & Cross Product, Scalar & Vector Triple Product
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The unit tangent vector on the curve \(x=t^{2}+1, y=4 t-3, z=2 t^{2}-6 t\) at the point where \(t=2\) is equal to
(a) \(\frac{2}{3} \hat{i}+\frac{2}{3} \hat{j}+\frac{1}{3} \hat{k}\)
(b) \(\frac{2}{3} \hat{i}-\frac{2}{3} \hat{j}-\frac{1}{3} \hat{k}\)
(c) \(\frac{2}{3} \hat{i}+\frac{2}{3} \hat{j}-\frac{1}{3} \hat{k}\)
(d) \(\frac{2}{3} \hat{i}-\frac{2}{3} \hat{j}+\frac{1}{3} \hat{k}\)
questions.onlyq_text: The unit tangent vector on the curve \(x=t^{2}+1, y=4 t-3, z=2 t^{2}-6 t\) at the point where \(t=2\) is equal to

sol_html.solution:
Given \(\vec{r}=\left(t^{2}+1\right) \hat{\imath}+(4 t-3) \hat{\jmath}+\left(2 t^{2}-6 t\right) \hat{k}\)

A vector tangent to the curve is  \(\vec{T}=\frac{d \vec{r}}{d t}\)

\[ \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow & \vec{T}=2 t \hat{i}+4 \hat{\jmath}+(4 t-6) \hat{k} \\ \text { If } t=2, & \vec{T}=4 \hat{\imath}+4 \hat{j}+2 \hat{k} \end{aligned} \]

and a unit vector along \(\vec{T}\) is \(\hat{T}\)

\[ \hat{T}=\frac{\vec{T}}{|\vec{T}|}=\frac{4 \hat{i}+4 \hat{j}+2 \hat{k}}{\sqrt{16+16+4}}=\frac{2}{3} \hat{i}+\frac{2}{3} \hat{j}+\frac{1}{3} \hat{k} \]

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The angle between the tangents to the curve \(\vec{r}=t^{2} \hat{i}+2 t \hat{j}-t^{3} \hat{k}\) at the point \(t= \pm 1\) will be
(a) \(\cos ^{-1}\left(\frac{3}{17}\right)\)
(b) \(\cos ^{-1}\left(\frac{6}{17}\right)\)
(c) \(\cos ^{-1}\left(\frac{9}{17}\right)\)
(d) \(\cos ^{-1}\left(\frac{11}{17}\right)\)
questions.onlyq_text: The angle between the tangents to the curve \(\vec{r}=t^{2} \hat{i}+2 t \hat{j}-t^{3} \hat{k}\) at the point \(t= \pm 1\) will be

sol_html.solution:
\[ \begin{aligned} \vec{r} & =t^{2} \hat{i}+2 t \hat{j}-t^{3} \hat{k} \\ \vec{T} & =\frac{d \vec{k}}{d t}=2 t \hat{\imath}+2 \hat{j}-3 t^{2} \hat{k} \\ \vec{T}_{1}(1) & =2 \hat{\imath}+2 \hat{\jmath}-3 \hat{k} \quad \& \quad \vec{T}_{2}(-1)=-2 \hat{\imath}+2 \hat{\jmath}-3 \hat{k} \end{aligned} \]

Now angle b/w  \(\overrightarrow{T_{1}} \& \overrightarrow{T_{2}}\) is Given by

cos θ=T1→ . T2→ T1→T2→=-4+4+917=917

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The unit vector tangent to the curve \(x=\sin t, y=\cos t, z=t\) at \(t=\pi / 4\) will be
(a) \(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}(\hat{i}-\hat{j}+\hat{k})\)
(b) \(-\frac{1}{2} \hat{i}+\frac{1}{2} \hat{j}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \hat{k}\)
(c) \(\frac{1}{2} \hat{i}-\frac{1}{2} \hat{j}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \hat{k}\)
(d) \(\frac{1}{4} \hat{i}-\frac{1}{4} \hat{j}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \hat{k}\)
questions.onlyq_text: The unit vector tangent to the curve \(x=\sin t, y=\cos t, z=t\) at \(t=\pi / 4\) will be

sol_html.solution:
Given \(\quad \vec{r}=\sin t \hat{\imath}+\cos t \hat{\jmath}+t \hat{k}\)

tangent vector \(\vec{T}=\frac{d \vec{r}}{d t}=\cos t \hat{\imath}-\sin t \hat{\jmath}+\hat{k}\)

\[ \begin{array}{l} \left.\vec{T}\right|_{t=\frac{\pi}{4}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \hat{\imath}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \hat{\jmath}+\hat{k} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \hat{T}=\frac{\vec{T}}{|\vec{T}|}=\frac{1}{2} \hat{i}-\frac{1}{2} \hat{\jmath}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \hat{k} \end{array} \]

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
An unit vector normal to the surface \(z=x^{2}+y^{2}\) at the point \((1,2,5)\) is
(a)\(\frac{\hat{i}+2 \hat{j}-\hat{k}}{\sqrt{6}}\)
(b) \(\frac{\hat{i}+\hat{j}-\hat{k}}{\sqrt{3}}\)
(c) \(\frac{2 \hat{i}+4 \hat{j}-\hat{k}}{\sqrt{21}}\)
(d) \(\frac{\hat{i}+2 \hat{j}-\hat{k}}{\sqrt{6}}\)
questions.onlyq_text: An unit vector normal to the surface \(z=x^{2}+y^{2}\) at the point \((1,2,5)\) is

sol_html.solution:
A vector normal to the Surface \(S(x, y, z)\) is \(\vec{ abla} S\)

Given \(S=x^{2}+y^{2}-z\)

\[ egin{array}{l} \vec{ abla} S=2 x \hat{\imath}+2 y \hat{\jmath}-\hat{k} \ \left.\vec{ abla} S ight|_{(1,2,5)}=2 \hat{\imath}+4 \hat{\jmath}-\hat{k} \end{array} \]

unit vector is \( rac{\vec{ abla} S}{|\vec{ abla} S|}= rac{2 \hat{\imath}+4 \hat{\jmath}-\hat{k}}{\sqrt{21}}\)

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The equation of a surface of is given as \(z= \pm \sqrt{\frac{3}{2} x^{2}+\frac{3}{2} y^{2}}\). The unit normal to the surface at the point \(A\left(\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}, 0,1\right)\) is
(a) \(\sqrt{\frac{3}{5}} \hat{i}+\frac{2}{\sqrt{10}} \hat{k}\)
(b) \(\sqrt{\frac{3}{10}} \hat{i}+\frac{2}{\sqrt{10}} \hat{j}\)
(c) \(\sqrt{\frac{3}{5}} \hat{i}+\frac{2}{\sqrt{5}} \hat{k}\)
(d) \(\sqrt{\frac{3}{5}} \hat{i}-\frac{2}{\sqrt{10}} \hat{k}\)
questions.onlyq_text: The equation of a surface of is given as \(z= \pm \sqrt{\frac{3}{2} x^{2}+\frac{3}{2} y^{2}}\). The unit normal to the surface at the point \(A\left(\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}, 0,1\right)\) is

sol_html.solution:
\[ egin{array}{l} S= \pm \sqrt{ rac{3}{2} x^{2}+ rac{3}{2} y^{2}} -z\ \vec{ abla} S= \pm rac{3 x}{2 \sqrt{ rac{3}{2} x^{2}+ rac{3}{2} y^{2}}} \hat{\imath} \pm rac{2 y}{2 \sqrt{ rac{3}{2} x^{2}+ rac{3}{2} y^{2}}} \hat{\jmath}-\hat{k} \ \left.\vec{ abla} S ight|_{\left(\sqrt{ rac{2}{3}}, 0,1 ight)}= \pm rac{\sqrt{3}}{\sqrt{2}} \hat{\imath}-\hat{k} \end{array} \]

Unit vector is civen by \( rac{\vec{V} s}{|\vec{ abla} s|}= rac{ \pm rac{\sqrt{3}}{\sqrt{2}} \hat{i}-\hat{k}}{\sqrt{ rac{3}{2}+1}}\)

\[ egin{array}{l} = \pm rac{\sqrt{3}}{\sqrt{5}} \hat{\imath}- rac{\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{5}} \hat{k} \ = \pm \sqrt{ rac{3}{5}} \hat{\imath}- rac{2}{\sqrt{10}} \hat{k} \end{array} \]

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
If the surface \(5 x^{2}-2 b y z=9 x\) be orthogonal to the surface \(4 x^{2} y+z^{3}=4\) at the point \((1,1,-2)\), then \(\mathrm{b}\) is
(a) 0
(b) 1
(c) 2
(d) 3
questions.onlyq_text: If the surface \(5 x^{2}-2 b y z=9 x\) be orthogonal to the surface \(4 x^{2} y+z^{3}=4\) at the point \((1,1,-2)\), then \(\mathrm{b}\) is

sol_html.solution:
Surface \(\left(S_{1} ight)=5 x^{2}-9 x-2 \operatorname{byz} z \quad \& \quad\) Surface \(\left(S_{2} ight)=4 x^{2} y+z^{3}-4\)

\[ egin{array}{l|l} \vec{ abla} S_{1}=(10 x-9) \hat{\imath}-2 b z \hat{\jmath}-2 b y \hat{k} & \vec{ abla} S_{2}=8 x y \hat{\imath}+4 x^{2} \hat{\jmath}+3 z^{2} \hat{k} \ \left.\vec{ abla} S_{1} ight|_{\substack{(1,1,-2)}}=\hat{\imath}+4 b \hat{\jmath}-2 b \hat{k} & \left.\vec{ abla} S_{2} ight|_{(1,1,-2)}=8 \hat{\imath}+4 \hat{\jmath}+12 \hat{k} \end{array} \]

Given the surfaces are perpendiculara so \(\vec{ abla} S_{1} \cdot \vec{ abla} S_{2}=0\)

\[ egin{array}{l} \Rightarrow 8+16 b-24 b=0 \ \Rightarrow 8=8 b \ \Rightarrow b=1 \end{array} \]

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The surface \(a x^{2}-b y z=(a+2) x\) will be orthogonal to the surface \(4 x^{2} y+z^{3}=4\) at the point \((1,-1,2)\). Which of the following relations is true for ' \(a\) ' and ' \(b\) '?
(a) \(a-b=4\)
(b) \(2 a-b=4\)
(c) \(a=3 b\)
(d) \(3 a+b=9\)
questions.onlyq_text: The surface \(a x^{2}-b y z=(a+2) x\) will be orthogonal to the surface \(4 x^{2} y+z^{3}=4\) at the point \((1,-1,2)\). Which of the following relations is true for ' \(a\) ' and ' \(b\) '?

sol_html.solution:
Surface \(S_{1}=a x^{2}-\) byz \(-(a+2) x \quad \& \quad\) surface \(S_{2}=4 x^{2} y+z^{3}-4\)

\[ egin{array}{l|l} \vec{ abla} S_{1}=(2 a x-(a+2)) \hat{\imath}-b z \hat{\jmath}-b y \hat{k} & \vec{ abla} S_{2}=8 y \hat{\imath}+4 x^{2} \hat{\jmath}+3 z^{2} \hat{k} \ \left.\vec{ abla} S_{1} ight|_{(1,-1,2)}=(a-2) \hat{\imath}-2 b \hat{\jmath}+b \hat{k} & \left.\vec{ abla} S_{2} ight|_{(1,-1,2)}=-8 \hat{\imath}+4 \hat{\jmath}+12 \hat{k} \end{array} \]

these two Surfaces are orthogonal so \(\vec{ abla} S_{1} \cdot \vec{ abla} S_{2}=0\)

\[ egin{array}{l} \Rightarrow-8(a-2)-8 b+12 b=0 \ \Rightarrow-8 a+16+4 b=0 \ \Rightarrow-2 a+b=-4 \ \Rightarrow 2 a-b=4 \end{array} \]

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
A sphere of unit radius is centered at the origin. The unit normal at a point \((x, y, z)\) on the surface of the sphere will be
(a) \(\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}, \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}, \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)\)
(b) \(\left(\frac{x}{\sqrt{3}}, \frac{y}{\sqrt{3}}, \frac{z}{\sqrt{3}}\right)\)
(c) \(\left(\frac{x}{\sqrt{2}}, \frac{y}{\sqrt{2}}, \frac{z}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\)
(d) \((x, y, z)\)
questions.onlyq_text: A sphere of unit radius is centered at the origin. The unit normal at a point \((x, y, z)\) on the surface of the sphere will be

sol_html.solution:
Equation of Sphere Centered at origin is \(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=r^{2}\)

for unit radius it is \(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=1\)

the normal vertor \(\vec{ abla} S=2 x \hat{i}+2 y \hat{j}+2 z \hat{k}\)

\[ egin{aligned} ext { unit normal vector is } & = rac{\vec{ abla} s}{|\vec{ abla} s|}= rac{2 x \hat{\imath}+2 y \hat{\jmath}+2 z \hat{k}}{2 \sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}} \ & =x \hat{i}+y \hat{\jmath}+z \hat{k} \quad herefore\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=1 ight) \end{aligned} \]

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The normal vector to the surface \(x y=z^{2}\) at the point \(\mathrm{P}(1,1,1)\) is
(a) \(2 \hat{i}+\hat{j}+2 \hat{k}\)
(b) \(\hat{i}-\hat{j}+2 \hat{k}\)
(c) \(\hat{i}-\hat{j}-2 \hat{k}\)
(d) \(\hat{i}+\hat{j}-2 \hat{k}\)
questions.onlyq_text: The normal vector to the surface \(x y=z^{2}\) at the point \(\mathrm{P}(1,1,1)\) is

sol_html.solution:
Given Surface \(S=x y-z^{2}\)

normal vector is \(\vec{\nabla} S=y \hat{\imath}+x \hat{\jmath}-2 z \hat{k}\)

\[ \left.\vec{\nabla} s\right|_{(1,1,1)}=\hat{\imath}+\hat{\jmath}-2 \hat{k} \]

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
Given: \(\varphi(x, y, z)=m x^{2}+y+z, \vec{a}=2 \hat{i}-3 \hat{j}+\hat{k}\). If \(\vec{\nabla} \varphi\) at the point \(\mathrm{P}(1,0,1)\) is perpendicular to \(\vec{a}\), then \(m\) is equal to
(a) 0
(b) \(3 / 2\)
(c) \(1 / 2\)
(d) \(-5 / 2\)
questions.onlyq_text: Given: \(\varphi(x, y, z)=m x^{2}+y+z, \vec{a}=2 \hat{i}-3 \hat{j}+\hat{k}\). If \(\vec{\nabla} \varphi\) at the point \(\mathrm{P}(1,0,1)\) is perpendicular to \(\vec{a}\), then \(m\) is equal to

sol_html.solution:
\[ egin{array}{l} \vec{ abla} \phi=2 m x \hat{\imath}+\hat{\jmath}+\hat{k} \ \left.\vec{ abla} \phi ight|_{(1,0,1)}=2 m \hat{\imath}+\hat{\jmath}+\hat{k} \end{array} \]

Given \(\vec{ abla} \phi\) is perpendicular to \(\vec{a}\)

\[ egin{array}{l} \Rightarrow 4 m-3+1=0 \ \Rightarrow m= rac{1}{2} \end{array} \]

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The temperatu of the points in space is given by \(T(x, y, z)=x^{2}+y^{2}-z\). A mosquito located at \((1,1,2)\) desires to fly in such a direction that it will get warm as soon as possible. The mosquito should move in the direction of
(a) \(\frac{2 \hat{i}+2 \hat{j}-\hat{k}}{3}\)
(b) \(\frac{2 \hat{i}-2 \hat{j}+\hat{k}}{3}\)
(c) \(\frac{\hat{i}-2 \hat{j}+\hat{k}}{\sqrt{6}}\)
(d) \(\frac{\hat{i}-2 \hat{j}-\hat{k}}{\sqrt{6}}\)
questions.onlyq_text: The temperatu of the points in space is given by \(T(x, y, z)=x^{2}+y^{2}-z\). A mosquito located at \((1,1,2)\) desires to fly in such a direction that it will get warm as soon as possible. The mosquito should move in the direction of

sol_html.solution:
The temperature function is given by \(T=x^{2}+y^{2}-z\)

mosquito will get warm as soon as in the direction of \(\vec{ abla} T\)

\[ egin{aligned} herefore & \vec{ abla} T=2 x \hat{i}+2 y \hat{j}-\hat{k} \ & \left.\vec{ abla} T ight|_{(1,1,2)}=2 \hat{i}+2 \hat{j}-\hat{k} \end{aligned} \]

So the mosquito should move in the direction of \( rac{\vec{ abla} T}{|\vec{ abla} T|}= rac{2 \hat{i}+2 \hat{j}-\hat{k}}{3}\)

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.concept_html:
Gradient:

For a scalar function \(\phi(x, y, z)\), the gradient is the maximum rate of change which is  given by-

\[ \operatorname{grad} \phi=\nabla \phi \Rightarrow\left(\hat{i} \frac{\partial}{\partial x}+\hat{j} \frac{\partial}{\partial y}+\hat{k} \frac{\partial}{\partial z}\right) \phi \]

Directional derivative: It gives the rate of change of scalar point function in a particular direction. The maximum magnitude of the directional derivative is the magnitude of the gradient.
questions.ocrQuestion:
The maximum value of direction derivative of \(\varphi=x^{2}-2 y^{2}+4 z^{2}\) at the point \((1,1,-1)\) is equal to
(a) \(6 \sqrt{7 / 3}\)
(b) \(\sqrt{7 / 3}\)
(c) 84
(d) \(3 \sqrt{3 / 7}\)
questions.onlyq_text: The maximum value of direction derivative of \(\varphi=x^{2}-2 y^{2}+4 z^{2}\) at the point \((1,1,-1)\) is equal to

sol_html.solution:
the maximum value of dirertional derivative is \(|\vec{ abla} \phi|\)

\[ egin{array}{l} \vec{ abla} \phi=2 x \hat{\imath}-4 y \hat{\jmath}+8 z \hat{k} \ \left.\vec{ abla} \phi ight|_{(1,1,-1)}=2 \hat{\imath}-4 \hat{\jmath}-8 \hat{k} \ |\vec{ abla} \phi|=\sqrt{4+16+64}=\sqrt{84}=6 \sqrt{ rac{7}{3}} \ \end{array} \]

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The directions along which there is no change in the value of the function \(f(x, y)=e^{\left(x^{2}+x y\right)}\) at the point \((3,-2)\) are equal to
(a) \(0.6 \hat{i}-0.8 \hat{j},-0.6 \hat{i}+0.8 \hat{j}\)
(b) \(-0.6 \hat{i}-0.8 \hat{j}, 0.6 \hat{i}+0.8 \hat{j}\)
(c) \(-0.6 \hat{i}-0.8 \hat{j}, 0.6 \hat{i}-0.8 \hat{j}\)
(d) \(0.6 \hat{i}+0.8 \hat{j},-0.6 \hat{i}+0.8 \hat{j}\)
questions.onlyq_text: The directions along which there is no change in the value of the function \(f(x, y)=e^{\left(x^{2}+x y\right)}\) at the point \((3,-2)\) are equal to

sol_html.solution:
\[ egin{array}{l} f(x)=e^{\left(x^{2}+x y ight)} \ \vec{ abla} f=e^{\left(x^{2}+x y ight)}(2 x+y) \hat{\imath}+e^{\left(x^{2}+x y ight)} x \hat{\jmath} \ \left.\vec{ abla} f ight|_{(3,-2)}=e^{3}(4 \hat{\imath}+3 \hat{\jmath}) \end{array} \]

the direction which is perpendicular to \(\vec{ abla} f\) is that direction along which there is no change in the value of the function. By looking at signs of the vectors we can easily recognize the vectors which are perpendicular to \(\vec{ abla} f\). only the vectors in option (a) are perpendicular. (Dot product is zero)
